title: The Great Flood
shortSummary: Genesis 7 recounts God's command to Noah to enter the ark with his family and the animals, followed by the onset of the worldwide flood that destroys all life outside the ark. This chapter highlights God's judgment on a sinful world and His provision of salvation through Noah's obedience.
timeline: c. 2500 BC - The Flood during Noah's lifetime

keyCharacters.name: Noah
keyCharacters.description: A righteous man chosen by God to build the ark and preserve life during the flood.

keyCharacters.name: Shem
keyCharacters.description: One of Noah's sons who entered the ark with his family.

keyCharacters.name: Ham
keyCharacters.description: Another son of Noah who accompanied him into the ark.

keyCharacters.name: Japheth
keyCharacters.description: Noah's third son, also saved in the ark with his family.

definitions.definition: Animals considered ceremonially pure and suitable for sacrifice or eating, taken by sevens into the ark.
The large vessel built by Noah to preserve his family and animals from the flood.
Sources of subterranean water that burst forth to contribute to the floodwaters.
The sky or heavens opening to release rain during the flood.

outline.heading: God’s Command to Enter the Ark
outline.description: God instructs Noah to bring his family and specified numbers of clean and unclean animals into the ark, emphasizing Noah's righteousness and obedience.

outline.heading: Entry into the Ark and Preparation for the Flood
outline.description: Noah, his family, and the animals enter the ark as God commands, and the LORD seals the ark, marking the final preparation before the flood begins.

outline.heading: The Flood Begins
outline.description: The floodwaters rise for forty days and nights, covering even the highest mountains, destroying all living creatures outside the ark, while Noah and those with him remain safe inside.

application: Trust in God’s provision and protection even when circumstances seem overwhelming, as Noah did by entering the ark.
Obey God’s commands fully and promptly, recognizing that obedience brings deliverance.
Recognize the seriousness of sin and God’s righteous judgment, motivating repentance and faith.
Maintain faith and perseverance during trials, knowing God is sovereign over all events.

keyVerses.text: And the LORD said unto Noah, Come thou and all thy house into the ark; for thee have I seen righteous before me in this generation.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights Noah’s righteousness and God’s invitation to salvation amid judgment.

keyVerses.text: And they that went in, went in male and female of all flesh, as God had commanded him: and the LORD shut him in.
keyVerses.significance: God’s sovereign protection is demonstrated as He seals the ark, ensuring Noah’s safety.

keyVerses.text: And all flesh died that moved upon the earth, both of fowl, and of cattle, and of beast, and of every creeping thing that creepeth upon the earth, and every man:
keyVerses.significance: This verse shows the comprehensive nature of God’s judgment on sin through the flood.

keyVerses.text: And the waters prevailed upon the earth an hundred and fifty days.
keyVerses.significance: The prolonged duration of the flood emphasizes the completeness of God’s judgment and the severity of the event.
